DVD review: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban
 
 This third Harry Potter film brought a change of director and a dramatic visual shake-up that really shines on DVD.
 
 Gone are the warm, bright colours found in the two earlier films, Alfonso Cuaron brings in a bleak and cold feel that is simply gorgeous - and looks even better here than in the cinema. It is all part of the progression of Harry's story into darker areas, but you'll spend time just marvelling at the beautiful Hogwarts landscape.
 
 This is the first Potter film where you get so lost in the screen adaptation that you forget the book. It is the third year at Hogwarts and studies are interrupted, as they always are, by a calamity that only Harry, Ron and Hermione can put right.
 
 It sounds corny. But Harry is no longer the winsome hero, he is a moody teenager and Daniel Radcliffe pulls it off very well. Emma Watson is ever better as Hermione, and the young stars are joined by the usual myriad famous actors including Gary Oldman and Emma Thompson. The film itself is the reason to buy this DVD. But it is laden with behind-the-scenes extras, including funny, if shallow, interviews with all the main cast. But what seems like a long list of features can be swiftly whittled down to the few that you are going to watch. Younger viewers will go for the games which include a Magic You May Have Missed memory test, and Crookshanks chasing off after Scabbers. Adult viewers will ignore those and go straight to the deleted scenes. You will understand why they were deleted but it is fun to see more footage - and not have to hunt through endless menus to find it, as we did on the first Harry Potter DVD. The most interesting pieces are an interview with JK Rowling in Creating The Vision and Conjuring A Scene, a short featurette about the making of the film's big moments.

DVD review: "Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban"

This third Harry Potter film has undergone a change in director, cinematography, and tone compared to previous installments, bringing about a fresh and gothic feel that is visually stunning. The warm, bright colors found in the two earlier films have been replaced with a bleak and cold look, which further enhances the moody tone of the story and character development.

Throughout this film, you get lost in the screen adaptation that doesn't require constant interruptions by the book. The calamitous events are handled well with Daniel Radcliffe portraying Harry as a more moody teenager who is not quite the winsome hero as he once was. Emma Watson also shines as Hermione, and the young stars are joined by the usual cast of familiar actors, including Gary Oldman and Emma Thompson.

The film's bonus features include behind-the-scenes interviews with the main cast and director Alfonso Cuaron, funny games, such as a memory test for the younger viewers, and deleted scenes, which are entertaining but not essential to watching the movie. Younger viewers will enjoy the "Magic You May Have Missed" feature that includes memories of previous films that you may have missed while watching the DVD. Adult viewers can skip through the "Deleted Scenes" section and choose from a few fun pieces, such as an interview with JK Rowling discussing creating the vision for the film and connecting scenes.

The most interesting featurette is "Conjuering A Scene," which provides insight into the making of big moments in the story, while the short featurette "Creating The Vision" showcases how the film's gothic aesthetic was brought to life.

This third installment of the Harry Potter series boasts drastic visual changes from the previous films, offering viewers an unprecedented glimpse into the darker corners of J.K. Rowling's beloved universe. The film is directed by Alfonso Cuaron, who brings his distinctive style to the forefront, resulting in a breathtaking visual experience that showcases the vastness and depth of the Hogwarts landscape while simultaneously introducing the story into darker areas.

The third installment introduces us to Harry's year at Hogwarts, where the students are put through their paces during the summer break. This time, Harry is no longer the charming hero but a moody teenager dealing with new responsibilities and learning about his own emotions. As always, Daniel Radcliffe delivers an exceptional performance as the young protagonist, delivering a powerful performance that resonates throughout the film.

While the majority of the movie is filled with action and adventure, there are some unexpected twists along the way, highlighted by the presence of Gary Oldman and Emma Watson. The interviews between the actors reveal a sense of camaraderie and vulnerability that extends beyond the screenplay, providing viewers with insight into the characters' lives outside of the movie's storyline.

The deleted scenes on this DVD are an interesting inclusion for fans of the series, offering a glimpse into the creation of certain scenes and giving fans a behind-the-scenes look at the movie. The most interesting piece is an interview with JK Rowling, who provides insights into the process of creating the film's big moments, including discussing the challenges of crafting Harry's transformation from underdog to legendary hero.

Overall, this third installment of the Harry Potter series offers a fresh perspective on an enchanting world, offering viewers an unprecedented glimpse into the darker corners of J.K. Rowling's beloved universe while introducing Harry into new areas. With its stunning visuals and thought-provoking storyline, this DVD is definitely worth adding to your collection.
